repnme.cdata!:
Czech Republic - Kyjov waste heat
            utilization : global environmental facility (GEF)

abstracts.cdata!:
The energy sector in the Czech Republic
            faces a set of challenges common to many other Central and
            East European countries. In October 1993, the Czech Republic
            signed the United Nation (UN) framework convention on
            climate change, and has since agreed to undertake efforts to
            reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and to meet the requirement
            of stabilizing emissions at or below 1990 levels by the year
            2000. This project was presented by the Government of the
            Czech Republic for global environmental facility (GEF)
            financing following a complicated and lengthy process of
            project identification, analysis, and priority setting. The
            project will: (a) reduce emissions of greenhouse gases from
            the Kyjov district heating system, by increasing the energy
            efficiency and reliability of heat and power supply to the
            Vetropak Moravia glass factory and heat supply to the city
            of Kyjov; and (b) achieve local environmental benefits by
            reducing the proportion of lignite in the fuel-mix for heat
            and power generation.

repnme.cdata!:
Czech Republic - Kyjov Waste Heat
            Utilization Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory, while project sustainability is rated as
            likely. Both World Bank and Borrower performances were
            adjudged as highly satisfactory. Lessons learned include the
            following: Targets of specific gas consumption, estimated by
            the project and stipulated in the turn-key contract, could
            not be fully realized during the trial operation, and the
            district heating company (TPK) had to settle for a higher
            value because of contractual inconsistencies. Second,
            technical problems with one waste heat boiler at the glass
            factory postponed the implementation and start-up of the
            second waste heat boiler until the technical problems of the
            first boiler were solved. The resulting higher fuel
            consumption of gas turbines is not critical to achieving the
            objective to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, but can lead
            to higher operating costs and therefore reduced profits than
            those . The boiler should have been tested properly at the
            beginning of the operation to anticipate problems due to the
            technological process of glass production--some mechanical
            parts of the boiler could not work properly with the
            contaminated air and the boiler had to be cleaned
            frequently. It is difficult for a small independent power
            producer to stay within a long-term contract with the
            electric grid company if the production cost is not
            competitive. The existing price structure would improved by
            an electricity price increase to recognize that new plants
            will be required in the future.
